(Try e.*t after checking 'Regular Exp...') ‚Äï‚Äï A few Settings. If the screen labels get wacky, just exit & relaunch the app. Despite the minor flaws, I like the one-screen setup & go. [me:KitKat]

I used the app to search for names in a directory with 20 text files (from 247KB up to 3927KB). The search uses regular expressions and ignores case. This app can really search for what I need to look for in the document. On my mobile phone (2 Cores 1.2GHz), the search process takes about 30 seconds, maybe up to 40 seconds to check the result for all the files. The same search process takes about 15 to 20 seconds On a tablet pc (4 Cores 1.3GHz). My default document viewer is having trouble opening these moderately big sized txt files  but with aGrep, opening and viewing the text within the search results is amazingly fast. It is also easy to cancel the searching so you can quickly change the search parameters if you made a mistake on your input. (Doing all this search process on a mainstream desktop PC will display the results instantaneously)  I don't know if it is about my Phone's processing power that the search result takes some time. From the apps that I have tried out so far, this is the only one that can do the task. Now, I'm just checking if there are other apps that can do it faster.

This little search utility is a handy grep-like program for your phone.  In some ways, the regex supported is more advanced than grep, for instance, I was able to do lookaheads - (?=EXP) that you can't do in grep, presumably because this uses java regular expressions instead of POSIX regular expressions.  I give it 5 stars because it is really quite useful, but I do have one little suggestion: while I do like the mode of searching in specific folders and with specific file extensions, sometimes I want to search only a single file, even if there are other files with the same extension in that folder.  So, being able to specify only certain files (instead of which folders/extensions) would be useful in addition to the search mode that already exists.
Works well :)

I wrote a perl program like aGrep called igrep.  I use igrep on Mac, PCs, and Linux, but have searched and searched for a handheld app with igrep functionality.  THIS IS IT!  I use aGrep (and igrep) as a personal information manager, and could not live without it.  My thanks to the developer!  Dropbox interface would be a nice enhancement.  (For now, I use FolderSync Lite.)
